The inscription was found inside a building not far away from another identified as a synagogue, but see Introduction 6.4.1.1.2. Described in the text as – τινὰ τῶν ̓Ιουδαίων (one of the Jews), see Introduction 6.1.1.2.
So according to Thackeray in the Loeb Classical Library Josephus translation, vol. 3, pp. 627-9.
The text about him begins with the words: Ψήφισμα ̔Αλικαρνασέων (Decree of the [people of] Halicarnasus).
He suggested the motion that privileged the Jewish community of Halicarnasus. He may thus have been Jewish himself, though the text does not say so.
See Ben Zeev, Jewish Rights, 206.
In AJ 18:159 τοῦ ἀλαβάρχου. He is introduced in ̓Αλεξανδρείας.
He is a brother of Philo the philosopher (AJ 18:259) and princess Berenice’s father-in-law (AJ 19:277).

These are the first and last years in which he is mentioned in Josephus. In AJ 18:159 he is described as present in 36 CE in Alexandria, when Agrippa borrowed a large sum of money from him. In 40 CE he was released from prison by the emperor Claudius, after Caligula’s assassination, according to AJ19:276.
Described by Josephus in AJ 20:100 as τοῖς γὰρ πατρίοις ο̓κ ἐνέμεινεν οὑτος ἔθεσιν ([he] did not stand by the practices of his people).
These are the dates in which he is definitely mentioned in documents, see CPJ 2, 188-90.

This text of Philo is preserved only as fragments in Eusebius’ Praeparatio Evangelicaand in an Armenian translation. All editions of Philo state categorically that this text is a dialogue with an Alexander who rejects the Jewish concept of providence. In none of them, however, is his name recorded. I assume it is recorded in the Armenian version, but I have not seen it.

Usually identified with Tiberius Julius Alexander, see Colson, Philo 9 (Cambridge 1941) 447. But no ancient source identifies the two. He might be a Jewish philosopher opposing Philo’s views. On over-identification see vol. 1, Introduction 3.3, pp. 35-6.
The context in which he appears is an internal Jewish debate.
In chapter 19 we read that Paul ἐλθεῖν εἰς ̓̀Εφεσον (went to Ephesus Acts 19:1) where he met Alexander, who is described as προβαλό́των των ̓Ιουδαίων (one sent by the Jews).
Described in the text as ἐπιγνόντων δὲ ὃτι ̓Ιουδαῖος ἐστιν (knowing that he was a Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.1, p. 51.

Mentioned in this papyrus together with an Ishmael who is certainly Jewish, see Introduction 6.6. Their common complaint may indicate a family relationship, but this is not necessary, see Introduction 6.6.9.2.

See Introduction 2.1.
Jewishness suggested based on the fact that the ostracon was found in the “Jewish quarter” of Edfu, but see Introduction 6.1.5.2.

A certain Marcus (2) is mentioned by Josephus (AJ19:276) as being the nephew of Philo the philosopher and of having married Berenice, the daughter of King Agrippa. CPJ 2, 197-8, identified him with the Marcus Julius Alexander mentioned on these ostraca who is a perfect contemporary, see also Ilan, Integrating Women, 219. However, if the identification does not stand then he need not be Jewish.
These are his dates on the ostracon.

Rostovzeff, the original edition of the papyri identified him with Alexander son of King Herod and Mariamme (see under Alexander [3] in vol. 1, p. 258). However, CPJrejected this identification because of the dates of the papyri. Instead they suggested identifying him with another Jew, Alexander (3) the alabarch of Alexandria (Josephus, AJ, 18:159). However, note that in CPJ 420a this name appears as a father’s name (Γαίῳ ̓Ιουλίῳ ̓Αλεξάνδρου ) and in CPJ 420b the name is incomplete ([Γαίου] ̓Ιουλ[ί]ου ̓Αλεξάνδρου). Thus, they may not even be the same person. In any case, Josephus gives Alexander’s second name as Lysimachus (1) and not Gaius Julius.
The papyri are dated.

This papyrus is dated to the fourth century (early Christian) and is replete with biblical names. Some would interpret them as Jews (e.g. Fikhman, SCI 13 [1994] 213-4), but the editor cautiously noted “Also remarkable is the fact that this wooden board contains a certain concentration of ‘Jewish’ names … These names are probably connected with Christianization of the village of Kellis during the 4th century … as there seems no good reason to think that there was a kind of ‘Jewish quarter’ in the village or its neighborhood.” And see Introduction 6.6.7.

state.note: Tertullus (2) and Chrysa (3)’s son, the youth, murdered, aged 15

person.note: In Greek: νέος … κακὸς δέ με ἄνθρωπος ἀπώλεσεν (a bad person killed me) … ἔτη ιε’.

Jewishness was (not emphatically) suggested by the editor, based on the remarkable similarity of the inscription to IJO1, Arch 70-71, which also record the murder of children and a request for revenge from God (there described as Θεὸν τὸν ̔́Υψιστουν τὸν Κύριου τῶν πνευμάτων καὶ πάσης σαρκὸς – God most high, Lord of the spirits and all flesh [Num 16:22]; here described as Κύρει Παντοκράτωρ –– Lord the Almighty). On the similarity and non-Jewishness of Θεὸν τὸν ̔́Υψιστουνand Κύρει Παντοκράτωρ see Introduction 6.10.1.1. The main reason why this may be considered other than Jewish is the definitive date of this inscription 237/8 CE (just before the onset of Christianity), whereas the Delos inscriptions are dated on epigraphical grounds to the 2nd-1st centuries BCE.
The inscription is dated.

Jewishness is suggested based on son’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1. However, the reading is not quite clear. It is either ̓Ανάνιας (in which case he is probably Jewish) or ̓Ανάνιος (in which case he may not be). There is nothing else Jewish in the inscription and it is very old. Jewishness is supported by the antiquity of the inscription (when the name was typically Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.). But geography is a problem because of near absence of Jews in the Greek island of Ios, and in the entire Greek world in the Hellenistic era.
The editor dated the inscription to the Hellenistic era.

Designated in the inscription ̓Ιουδέῳ (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.3.
In Greek – Βερνικέος.

Identified as such because of his town of provenance, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.3.1, pp. 48-9. This person is recorded under Artemon (1) (G/M) in vol. 1, p. 268, but not included in the statistics, see Introduction 6.3.1 in that volume.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.

person.note: So in CIJ 619c.
So in CIJ 619d.

The inscriptions were found in a catacomb close to the Jewish one in Venosa but in itself is not decisively Jewish, see Introduction 6.5.3.1. Jewishness of inscription was suggested based on title πατήρ found in it, but see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.2.1.
Jewishness of inscription indicated by a menorah and other Jewish symbols, see Introduction 6.3.1.

The ethnic identity of this person is problematic. His son bears a biblical name but could be Christian because he is late, see Introduction 6.6.7. However, he serves as guard in a pagan temple, which is problematic for either, see Introduction 6.6.5.
The papyrus is dated.
Greek, WGE, 1246, interprets this as a place name.
In the Ukraine.

state.note: Claudius (8) Tiberius (5) Polycharmus (1), father of the synagogue

person.note: In Greek – ̔ πατὴρ τῆς ἐν Στόβιος συναγωγῆς.

This is a synagogue inscription, see Introduction 6.4.1.1.1. This man is described as Father of the Synagogue in Stobi, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.2, and as living his life according to the proscriptions of Judaism (κατὰ τὸν ̓Ιουδαϊσμὸν), see Introduction 6.1.1.
On this as a nickname see Williams, JSJ 38 (2007) 316.
The inscription is dated (311 according to the Macedonian era beginning in 146 BCE).
See Introduction 2.3.2.1, and also vol. 1, Introduction 2.2.3, p. 20.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. However, this is a list of names, none of them strictly Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
See Introduction 2.3.2.1.
In Russia, on the north-eastern coast of the Black Sea.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.

IJO 1, 330, wrote of the Hebrew inscriptions from the region “The dating given by Chwolson has no real basis, and the inscriptions are probably medieval.” One may assume he considered them all medieval based on the transitional pattern in all Europe, where in the Middle Ages Jews preferred to use Hebrew rather than the local scripts in their inscriptions, see Introduction 6.2.3.
See previous note.
In Latin – qui vixit annus p(lus) m(inus) XVIII.
The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1 and the Hebrew words – שלום על מנוחתך, see Introduction 6.2.2.
For the additional ι see Introduction 2.8.1.

On p. 313 Epiphanius claims that Basilides describes himself and his followers as “no longer Jews and … not yet … Christians (Α̓τὸς δὲ καῖ οἱ ἀπ’ α̓τοῦ ἐρωτώμενοι ̓Ιουδαίους μέν ἑουτοὺς μηκέτι εἰ̓ναι φάσκουσι Χριστιανοὺς μηκέτι γεγενῆσθαι ).” However, this could relate to theology rather than birth.
These are his dates.
This is a synagogue inscription, see Introduction 6.4.1.1.1.
For the interchange of e and i see Introduction 2.3.2.2.8.
Gregory speaks of “christianis mancipiis quae Iudaiei de Galliarum finibus emunt” (Christian slaves whom the Jews buy from the territory of Gaul). He is described as one of these Jews.
Described in the text as of the “Iudaiei,” see Introduction 6.1.1.1.
The letter is dated.

The inscription is bilingual, Hebrew-Latin. So in the Latin, and see also Introduction. 2.1.
The inscription was found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3. It is bilingual – Hebrew and Latin, see Introduction 6.2.2.
See Introduction 2.1. This probably derives from the form Βερενικιανιός, see Introduction 2.3. For the abbreviation see Introduction 2.3.1.
See above, n. 4.
In Greek – λογιστεύοντος.

Jewishness may be suggested based on title archisynagogus mentioned in the inscription, but in Greece this is not decisive, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.1. In this list Rajak collects all the non-Jewish archisynagogoi inscriptions. This is the most blatantly pagan inscription since it mentions the assembled worshippers of Zeus Hypsistos (Διὸς ̔Υψίστος), see Introduction 6.10.2.
The inscription is dated.

This is the Hebrew transliteration of the Greek Βοηθός, as recorded in Josephus, see Introduction 2.3.2.1. The Hebrew transliteration is assumed on the basis of the identification of the priestly family by this name mentioned in rabbinic literature with the priestly family by the same name mentioned in Josephus, see Stern, “Aspects of Jewish Society,” 604-6.

These are the dates of Ptolemy Philopatoir, who is mentioned in the writings of Demetrius as a contemporary, see Holladay, Fragments I, 51.
This papyrus is an account of a supply of bricks. This Demetrius is described as bringing them.

The person who buys bricks in this document rests on the Sabbath. Whether this was because the worker who delivers them (our Demetrius) is Jewish is doubtful. Perhaps the factory owner who sells them is Jewish, but his name is not mentioned in the document.
The editor writes “probably reign of Philadelphos.” These are his dates.

CPJ suggested that all persons listed in this papyrus are Jews, because some of them have biblical names, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2; and they come from the village of Samaria, but see Introduction 6.1.6.4.1.
The papyrus is dated to one of these two years.

According to Suetonius, he used to preach every Sabbath, see previous note. From this it may be inferred that he was a Jewish sage, but it is not explicitly stated in the text.

The inscription comes from Apollonia, and may have been described by Robinson, AJA 17 (1913) 185, as follows: “In regard to the date of these inscriptions from the tombs west of Apollonia, it should be noted that in several cases the seven-branched candlestick is roughly incised at the side of the entrance,” see Introduction 6.3.1.However, he may have referred to other tombs, see Introduction 6.5.5. The editor suggested the first name on this tombstone is [̓Ιου]δίων, which is obviously derived from Judah, see Introduction 6.6.8, but the remaining readable letters could be part of many other (non-Jewish) names.

This inscription is strikingly similar to CIJ 774, also from Apamea. The name of the wife is the same. The formulation of the epitaph is the same and it ends with a warning. However, while in CIJ 774 it ends with the mention of “the Jews [τ]ῶν Εἰυοδέων,” here it ends with a fine to be paid to the treasury (ταμεῖον). The similarity may suggest a communal affinity, but not necessarily Jewishness.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

This curse tablet calls on the God Iau for help. This is typically Jewish, and no other deities or demigods are evoked, see Introduction 6.10.1.6. However, in “magical” texts one can never know, and even if the invocation writer was a Jew, his client need not have been, and even if the client was Jewish, her slave need not have been, see Introduction 6.6.9.2.

IJO 1, 329, wrote “It is impossible to date Hebrew writings in an area where there are so few examples, and none with any internal dating.” One may assume he considered them all medieval based on the transitional pattern in all Europe, where in the Middle Ages Jews preferred to use Hebrew rather than the local scripts in their inscriptions, see Introduction 6.2.3.

This burial cave was identified as housing Jews from Cyrenaica, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.3.1.1, p. 49. This person is recorded in under Thaliarchus (1) (G/M) in vol. 1, p. 284, but not included in the statistics, see Introduction 6.3.1 in that volume, pp. 48-9.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
See Holladay, Fragments 1, 343.

See Introduction 6.1.6.4.On his possible identity with Thallus the Samaritan, and on other arguments in favor of his being Jewish see Holladay, Fragments 1, 343-4. See also H. A. Rigg, “Thallus: The Samaritan?” HTR 34 (1941) 111-9.

His provenance is nowhere mentioned. If he was Augustus secretary, as one scholar suggested (see Holladay, Fragments 1, 343) then he is Roman. If he was Samaritan, perhaps placing him in the Diaspora volume is false. I have simply placed him with most Greek-writing Jewish authors mentioned by Eusebius.
This is the date of Julius Sextus Africanus, the earliest author to quote him.
In Latin – vix ann XXI.
The inscription was found on a column outside the Jewish catacomb, but see Introduction 6.5.3.1. It is of members of the Sextus Pompeus family, probably not Jewish.
WGE, 481, records the form Θάρρα as the name of a city in India. The declension may be based on the form Θάρρας, see Introduction 2.3.3.7.2.
Described in the text as one of several Jews who had διάλεξις γέγονεν (conducted a dispute) with Christians.

He is portrayed in this text as disputing the Jewish side with the Christian bishop Silvester, and although is never specifically identified as Jewish, this is the most likely explanation of his presence.
These are Pope Silvester’s dates.
See Introduction 2.3.1.
Jewishness based on son’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.

This is Agrippa (1) (L/M) in vol. 1, p. 325.
He was the Jewish King Agrippa’s freedman. He was obviously born non-Jewish. Whether he had converted remains an unanswered question.
This is where the encounter between him and Agrippa first took place. He is mentioned under Thaumastus (1) (G/M) in vol. 1, p. 285, but not included in the statistics.
This is the year of Agrippa’s arrest, when we first encounter Thaumastus, see L. H. Feldman, Josephusvol. 9 (Loeb Classical Library; Cambridge MA 1965) 115.

Inscription identified as Jewish based on the formula θεῷ̔ψίστῳ (God most high), but see Introduction 6.10.1.1. IJO 2 rejected its Jewishness and did not include it in its corpus, see p. 53, n. 60.

The book in which he is mentionted is reputed to be by the historian Olympiodorus, who was active in the 5th century.

The document begins with the words Ψήφισμα Περγαμηνῶν (decree of the Pregamese) and he is described as ἀπεδεξάμεθα δὲ καὶ ἐπὶ τὴν βουλὴν καὶ τὴν ἐκκλησίαν τὸν Θεόδωρον ἀπολαβόντες τε τὴν ἐπιστολὴν παρ ’ α̓τοῦ … (we have admitted Theodorus to the council and assembly, accepting from him the letter …).
As a messenger from Rome, he represented the Jews before the council of Pergamum, so he was probably (but not certainly) Jewish.
The document is dated both to the days of Hyrcanus (2) (P/M) in vol. 1, p. 350. These are his dates.

Since he composed 2 Macc, he was most likely Jewish.
Paul is described in this text as coming εἰς Θεσσαλονίκην (Acts 17:1).
Paul was staying in his house in Thessalonica. He was probably Jewish because in the verses earlier we are led to understand that Paul managed to convert some of the Jews of the city.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.1, p. 51.
Perhaps identical with the previous.
Paul describes him with some others as οἱ συγγενεῖς μου (my kinsmen), perhaps indicating that he, like Paul, was Jewish, but this may be rhetorical kinship language.
These are Paul’s dates, see vol. 1, Introduction 7.1, p. 51.

This person is mentioned in a title of a book relating an old dispute between a Christian and a Jew, which is now lost. From the way the book is mentioned in Origen, it is not clear whether Jason or Papiscus was the Jew. I thus record them both.
I assume the dispute did not take place in Palestine, though I have no idea where it did take place.
This is the date Origen came to Caesarea, where he produced most of his literary works. The dispute of Jason and Papiscus was known both to Origen, and to Celsus, whom Origen refutes.
See Introduction 2.3.2.1.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. However, this is a list of names, none of them strictly Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
All witnesses in this document are described as οἱ ἕξ ̓Ιουδαῖοι (all six Jews), see Introduction 6.1.1.2.
The papyrus is dated.

His son is described in the papyrus together with another witness as οἱ δύο ̓Ιουδαῖοι τῶν διὰ Δωσιθέου τῆς πρώτης ἱππαρχίας (both Jews of the first hipparchy settled by Dositheus), see Introduction 6.1.4.
The papyrus is dated.

This contract, of which his son is the subject, is signed by six Jews. Thus, it is likely that he too was a Jew, but his son is described in this text as Παίων (a Paeonian), see Introduction 6.1.4.1.

This is another version of this person’s name in Epiph. Pan. 28. Epiphanius was not sure whether it was another name or whether he was another person, but because no such name exists in Greek, I assume this is a derogatory version of the person’s name, used by his opponents.
Described by Epiphanius as partly adhering to Judaism (προσέχειν τῷ ̓Ιουδαϊσμῷ). However, this term is sometimes used for Judaizing Christians, see Introduction 6.1.6.3.
In Greek – ἐπὶ ἀρχόντων.

This tomb includes the typical Jewish formulaἐν ἰρήνῃ κύμεσις α̓τοῦ (In peace his rest), see Introduction 6.10.3.5, but it is not from Rome. All this is circumstancial rather than direct evidence.

The editors thought the inscription Jewish because it mentions Τραιανησίων and it was assumed on comparison with the title “Augustinians” found in Jewish inscriptions (see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.1), that this was a Jewish community in Porto, which received its civic privileges from the emperor Trajan, but there is no other evidence for this premise. Also, the inscription is dedicated to θεοῦ μεγάλου Διωνύσου (of the Great God Dionysus), see Introduction 6.10.2.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

This papyrus is a list of names. None of them are specifically biblical, and it is only identified as Jewish because the editors thought the names were commonly used by Jews, see CPJ1, pp. 176-7, but this is not likely, see e.g. under Dositheus (G/M), n. 1.
Considered by the editor Jewish because of vicinity to Jewish tombs, but see Introduction 6.5.5.
In Greek – ξβ’.
Considered by the editor Jewish, because of the name Simon (85), but this is not necessary, see Introduction 6.6.4.
See Introduction 2.1.
Applebaum mentioned this person as possibly Jewish, because of Greek names he considered Jewish found in its vicinity, but see Introduction 6.5.5.
This is a Jewish synagogue donor inscription, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.2. He is one of the donors.
The inscription is dated.

person.note: For this sort of abbreviation see Introduction 2.3.1.
In Greek – λ’.

So the date of this tomb is calculated by the editor.
Appears only in some manuscripts, see B. Niese, Flavii Iosephi Opera 4 (Berlin 1895) 258.
In AJ 18:159 τοῦ ἀλαβάρχου. He is introduced in ̓Αλεξανδρείας.
He is a brother of Philon (1) the philosopher (AJ 18:259) and princess Berenice’s father-in-law (AJ 19:277), see under Berenice (2) (G/F) in vol. 1, p. 315.

These are the first and last years in which he is mentioned in Josephus. In AJ 18:159 he is described as present in 36 CE in Alexandria, when Agrippa borrowed a large sum of money from him. In 40 CE he was released from prison by the emperor Claudius after Caligula’s assassination, according to AJ19:276.
See Introduction 2.3.2.1.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. However, this is a list of names, none of them strictly Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.2.

This papyrus is a list of names. None of them specifically biblical, and only identified as such because the editors thought they were commonly used by Jews, see CPJ1, pp. 176-7, but this is not likely, see e.g. under Dositheus (G/M), n. 1.
In Greek – σο[φός].
This ostracon describes a feast presided over by a Jewish priest (Joseph [13]). Since it makes sense that this is a Jewish feast, I considered all participants Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1
In Greek – τῶν τριῶν Περσῶν (all three Persians). For evidence that this term means “debtor” see CPJ1, p. 51, n. 10, and PC 29 (2001), p. 98-9, n. 14.
Jewishness suggested based on father-in-law’s name (Isaac [9]), see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The papyrus is dated.
Jewishness indicated by affiliation to the politeuma, see Introduction 6.4.2.1, and by the mention of τῆι κώμηι ̓Ιουδαίος (the Jewish village), see Introduction 6.1.1.6.
The papyrus is dated.

The inscription was found inside a building not far away from another identified as a synagogue, but see Introduction 6.4.1.1.2. It mentions the word προσευχῆι, which may be (but in Greece in the 1st century CE not necessarily) a Jewish prayer house see Introduction 6.4.1.2.1.1, and IJO 1, p. 226-7.
Perhaps identical with the previous.
The inscription was found inside a building usually identified as a synagogue, but see Introduction 6.4.1.1.2. It mentions Θεῶ ̔Υψίστῳ (god most high), but see Introduction 6.10.1.1.
In Greek – ζ’.
Found in a tomb with Joshua (21) and Judah (77), see Introduction 6.5.5.
This is the date of another inscription in the tomb.

Jewishness suggested by editor based on the name Mariam (47) found on the same sarcophagus, but see Introduction 6.6.4. In Hierapolis Jewish graves are specifically marked as such, see Introduction 6.1.1.3, and this one is not. IJO 2 considered it not Jewish and did not include it in its corpus, see p. 399, n. 161.

state.note: Yiftah (1), of Ptolemais, dwells in Gortyn

person.note: In Greek – Πτολεμαιεὺς Γορτυνίων πρόξενος καὶ πολίτας.
Jewishness suggested based on other name, but see Introduction 6.6.3.
His father swears in the letter by Har Gerizim (in Greek ̔Αργαριζίν) the holy site of the Samaritans, see Introduction 6.1.6.4.
In Russia, on the north-eastern coast of the Black Sea.

This manumission inscription is similar to others performed in the Jewish synagogue in the region, but see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.3. The opening formula [Θεῷ̔ψ]ίσ[τῳ παντοκράτ ]ορι (God most high, ruler of all) was also considered Jewish, but see Introduction 6.10.1.1.
These are the dates of the king mentioned in the inscription, according to IJO 1, BS21.
The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
Described in the text as̓Ιουδέου (=Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.3.
Jewishness suggested based on brother’s name, but the inscription is late and may be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.
In Greek – ἀπελευθέρος. This refers to Agrippa (1) (L/M) in vol. 1, p. 325.
He was the Jewish King Agrippa’s freedman. He was obviously born non-Jewish. Whether he had himself converted remains an unanswered question.
This is where the encounter between him and Agrippa first took place.
This is the year of Agrippa’s arrest, when we encountered Marsuas, see L. H. Feldman, Josephusvol. 9 (Loeb Classical Library; Cambridge MA 1965) 115.
Jewishness indicated by reference to the archons of the politeuma, see Introduction 6.4.2.1. He is apparently a jailer and thus an official of the politeuma.
The papyrus is dated.
In Greek – ἐτῶν πέντε.
The inscription in the Alexandria Museum. Its exact provenance is unknown. Leontopolis provenance assumed based on artistic style.
Jewishness suggested based on father’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.6.

Described in the text as one of “Duo quidam primarii Judaeorom” (two of the leading Jews), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.
Severus, the bishop of Minorca, wrote in a letter dated to this year about the conversion of the Jews of Minorca.

In the Crimea.

There is nothing Jewish in this inscription except its typological similarity to other manumission inscriptions from the region, where the manumission was performed in the synagogue of the Jews, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.3. This inscription mentions the pagan gods Δία Γῆν ̔́Ηλιον (Zeus, Ge and Helios), see Introduction 6.10.2.
The inscription is dated to the reign of the king Tiberius Julius Sauromates II. These are his regnal years.

GLAJJ included this person in his corpus on the assumption that “verpus erat” refers to circumcision, and concluded that this was a Jewish actor in Rome. However, see Introduction 6.1.7.1.
This is Martial’s year of death.

person.note: In Greek – πατηρ συναγωγῆς τῶν Καρκαρησίων.

For this sort of form see Introduction 2.3.

Jewishness suggested based on the name Mattathias of the deceased next to him, but see under Mattathias (B/M) n. 1, and MAMA 9, p. 137, for the suggestion that it is an Anatolian name. It was not included in IJO 2, see p. 345, n. 10.
For this spelling variation see Introduction 2.3.3.2.
The inscription indicates that Piste is buried in his tomb. This may suggest but does not explicitely claim relationship.

Editors considered the woman buried with him as possibly Jewish because of her designation in the inscription – Πίστη καὶ Θεω͂ πιστή (Piste – faithful, also faithful to God). If he is buried with her she is probably his relative. However, she may not be, see Introduction 6.5.9, and see also under Piste (G/F), n. 2.

This papyrus is a list of names. None of them are specifically biblical, and they are only identified as Jewish because the editors thought they were commonly used by Jews, see CPJ1, pp. 176-7, but this is not likely, see e.g. under Dositheus (G/M), n. 1.

Described as disciple of Ceasarea (τῶν μαθητῶν ἀπὸ Καισαρείας) thus not converted by Paul but rather by another disciple and probably Jewish, as the discussion of the issue in the text indicates.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.1, p. 51.

CPJ suggested that all persons listed in this papyrus are Jews, because some of them have biblical names, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2; and they come from the village of Samaria, but see Introduction 6.1.6.4.1.
The papyrus is dated to either of these years.
My reading. CPJ read father and son’s name as one Θεδμνᾶ. And see also Introduction 2.3.1.
Paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.
The ostracon is dated.

state.note: Marcus (40) Aurelius (87), Aurelia (46) Artemia (2) Corcaina (1)’s husband

person.note: His niece (Aurelia [41] Artemia [1] - IJO 2, 216) is described as ̓Ιουδέᾳ (Jewess), but in this case he need not be, see Introduction 6.1.4, and Williams, ZPE 116 (1997) 261-2.
In Greek – ἔζησεν ἔτη δεκα.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3. Described in the inscription as ̔Εβραῖος (Hebrew), see Introduction 6.1.2.

Jewishness indicated by his son’s title ̓Ιουδαῖος (Jew, Judaean), see Introduction 6.1.4, but the man is described as seeing pagan gods in his dreams (see Introduction 6.10.2, and D. M. Lewis, “The First Greek Jew,” Journal of Semitic Studies 2 [1957] 264-6) and see also Cohen Beginnings of Jewishness, 96-8.
Designated in the inscription ̓Ιουδέῳ (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.3.

Jewishness indicated by the title ̓Ιουδαῖος (Jew, Judaean), see Introduction 6.1.1.5, but the man is described as seeing pagan gods in his dreams (see Introduction 6.10.2 and D. M. Lewis, “The First Greek Jew,” Journal of Semitic Studies 2 [1957] 264-6) and see also Cohen Beginnings of Jewishness, 96-8.
Mentioned in the same breath with Josephus, Philo and Aristobulus.
Eusebius mentions him here together with Philo and Josephus as ̓Ιουδαίοι (Jews) who recognized some of the truths of Christianity even before the edvent of Christ.
Since Eusebius mentions him together with two other Hellenistic-Jewish-Egyptian, Greek-writing authors, I assume, he was one too.
The man is described as ̓Ιουδαῖος (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.2.
The papyrus is dated to one of these years.
The editor interpreted this as Mar Musaius (mar being a Semitic title of distinction, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.4). IJO 2 suggested Μαρ as being an abbreviation of Latin Μάρκος, see p. 33.
IJO2 understood this is the title ἱαιρέος (priest), see p. 33. The loss of the α is obviously a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.2.

Jewishness indicated by mention of οἱ ̓Ιουδαίοι (the Jews) who set up the memorial, see Introduction 6.1.4. The biblical name of his father, Yair, also assists in the identification, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.

So in rabbinic literature. Rabbinic literature also uses this name for the Greek general Νικάνωρ of 1 Macc 7:39. For the transliteration see Introduction 2.3.2.1.

On the ossuary – ποιήσαντος τὰς θύρας. The identification of this Νεικάνοροςwith the “legendary” rabbinic ניקנור who made a set of gates for the Temple in Jerusalem seems, as already suggested by Klein, Corpus Inscriptionum, 18, beyond doubt, and against Schwartz, HUCA 62 (1991) 245-83, particularly 248-50.
Mentioned in rabbinic literature as contributing to the Temple in Jerusalem, and he is buried in an ossuary, see vol. 1, Introduction 4.1, p. 37.

See vol. 1, Introduction 6.3.1, p. 48-9. This person is recorded under Nicanor (2) (G/M) in vol. 1, p. 297, but not included in the statistics. He is described in rabbinic literature as producing gates for the Temple in Alexandria and bringing them with him, see bYoma 38a. If ̓̓Αλεξανδρέως mentioned on his ossuary is not a name, but means “Alexandrian,” then the information on the ossuary conforms to that in rabbinic literature.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.

Described in the papyrus together with another witness as οἱ δύο ̓Ιουδαῖοι τῶν διὰ Δωσιθέου τῆς πρώτης ἱππαρχίας (both Jews of the first hipparchy settled by Dositheus), see Introduction 6.1.1.2.

This is the date Origen came to Caesarea, where he produced most of his literary works. The dispute of Jason and Papiscus was known both to Origen, and to Celsus, whom Origen refutes.

This is a dedicatory inscription. Lifshitz, no. 84, thought it Jewish because of the title (πρεσβύτερος) therein and because of the initial blessing ΘΒ standing for Θεὸς Βοήθει (God protect) – a typical Jewish formula. However see Introduction 6.10.3.2. His other name could be Jewish, but see Introduction 6.6.7. IJO rejected its Jewishness.
The ostracon probably records one Jew (Yair [2]), but the other need not be, see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
The editor dated the ostracon to the Ptolemaic period.

The story occurs after Paul ἐλθεῖν εἰς ̓́Εφεσον (went to Ephesus, Acts 19:1) ἐν τῇ σχολῆ Τυράννου τινο͂ς (in a school of a certain Tyrannus, 19:9).

After leaving the synagogue in Ephesos, Paul went to this man’s house of study, where he further taught. It is thus not clear whether this was a Jew who accepted Paul’s teaching over and against that of his synagogue, or whether he was altogether a gentile.

His son is described in the text as ̓Ιουδαίου (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.2.
The papyrus is dated to either of these dates.
For the f transliteration see Introduction 2.3.2.2.4.

Found on a sarcophagus fragment, mentioning D(is) M(anibus) (gods of the underworld) but see Introduction 6.10.2.1. The fragmentary inscription clearly mentions Iudei cum (the Jews, with …). This suggests that the interred was indeed Jewish, see Introduction 6.1.4.
See Introduction 6.1.6.2.1.
The inscription is dated.

The inscription comes from Apollonia, and may have been described by Robinson, AJA 17 (1913), as follows: “In regard to the date of these inscriptions from the tombs west of Apollonia, it should be noted that in several cases the seven-branched candlestick is roughly incised at the side of the entrance,” see Introduction 6.3.1.However, he may have referred to other tombs, see Introduction 6.5.5. The editor suggested the first name on this tombstone is [̓Ιου]δίων, which is obviously derived from Judah, see Introduction 6.6.8,but the remaining readable letters could be part of many other (non-Jewish) names.
The inscription is dated.
On the single consonant π see Introduction 2.3.3.4.

Strubbe, “Curses,” 98-9, suggests the inscription may be Jewish based on its similarity to JIWE 2, 360, which was found in a Jewish cemetery in Rome, but that inscription was identified as Jewish because of its provenance (see Introduction 6.5.3), and not based on contents, which could be universal Graeco-Roman, and this inscription’s provenance is very different.
On this sort of name see Introduction 2.3.
Described in the text as ̓Ιουδαῖος τῆς ἐπιγονῆς (Jew of the epigone), see Introduction 6.1.1.2.
The papyrus is dated.
Described in the text as ̔ ἐκ τῶν ̓Ιουδαίων (of the Jews), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.
Epiphanius does not mention where he was active, but I suppose it was in the Greek-speaking Diaspora.
Epiphanius describes him as a contemporary of Celsus, who was active between 175 and 180 CE.
In Greek Στρηνείωνος. This is a name of a City in Crete (Στρῆνος), see WGE, 1448.
He is described as ̓Ιουδαίου (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.3. The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
He is the great Jewish philosopher. Here Josephus describes him as head of the delegation of the Jews from Alexandria (̔ προεστὼς τῶν ̓Ιουδαίων), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.
These are his dates according to Y. Amir, “Philo Judaeus (Philo of Alexandria),” EJ 13 (Jerusalem 1971) 409.
See Holladay, Fragments 2, 205-99.
Eusebius describes him as a poet who wrote about Jerusalem and the Temple, Abraham and Joseph, see Holladay, Fragments 2, 205.

For a discussion of his date and provenance see Holladay, Fragments2, 208-10, and see vol. 1, Introduction 6.3.1, pp. 48-9. This person is recorded under Philo (1) (G/M) in vol. 1, p. 311, but not included in the statistics.
So according to Holladay, Fragments 2, 208, since he predates Alexander Polyhistor.
Described with Papiscus as ̓Ιουδαιῶν (of the Jews), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.
If this dialogue took place at the end of the 7th or in the 8th century it is too late for the data in this lexicon, and is thus not included in the statistics.
I assume the dispute did not take place in Palestine, though I have no idea where it did take place.
This seems to be the internal dating of the composition, see McGiffert, Christian and Jew, 41-4.
This ostracon consists of a list of names. One of them (Joshua [3]) is Jewish so the editors considered them all Jews, but see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
CPJ only included this ostracon because it was found with other Jewish ostraca, in the “Jewish quarter” at Edfu, but see Introduction 6.1.5.2.
The ostracon is dated.
His grandson (Dosas [2]) paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.1.
The ostraca are dated.
See Introduction 2.3.1.
Jewishness suggested based on vicinity to persons with biblical names mentioned in the same document, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
See above, n. 17.

See Introduction 6.1.6.2.1.
The inscription is dated.
His wife is described in the inscription as Σαμαρεῖτις, see Introduction 6.1.6.4.
In Greek – ξη’.
Jewishness suggested based on the names Sarah (23) and Simon (75) mentioned in the inscription, but see Introduction 6.6.4 and 6.6.4.1, and Introduction 6.5.5.

The name Sarah (27) is found in the same tomb as his, but in Cyrenaica it need not be Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.4.1, and Introduction 6.5.5.
These dates are found on inscriptions in this tomb.
The editor thought the names of some of the interned in this tomb are Jewish, but see Introduction 6.5.5.
His son is buried in a cave with Joshua (22), see Introduction 6.5.5.
See Introduction 2.1.
Considered Jewish because of vicinity to other Jewish tombs, but see Introduction 6.5.5.
Applebaum mentioned this person as possibly Jewish, because he thought this Greek name was specifically Jewish, but see Introduction 6.5.5.
See previous note.
The inscription was found on a Jewish ossuary from Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.5.6.
In Greek – Κυρηναῖος, see vol. 1, Introduction 6.3.1, pp. 48-9. This person is recorded under Philo (3) (G/M) in vol. 1, p. 311, but not included in the statistics.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
His daughter is married to a Jew, “according with the laws of the Jews” ([κατὰ τὸν νόμον π ]ολιτικὸν τῶν [̓Ιου]δαίων), see Introduction 6.1.4.
The papyrus is dated.
In Greek – ἐπὶ ἀρχόντων.
This is a Jewish politeuma inscription, see Introduction 6.4.2.2.
The inscription is dated.

Money due to his granddaughter was deposited “in the archive of the Jews” (διὰ τοῦ τῶν ̓Ιουδαίων ἀρχείου ), see Introduction 6.4.3.Her debtor was obviously Jewish but he need not be, see Introduction 6.4.3.
The papyrus is dated.
Jewishness indicated by the affiliation to the politeuma (see Introduction 6.4.2.1) and by the mention of τῆι κώμηι ̓Ιουδαίος (the Jewish village, see Introduction 6.1.1.6).
The papyrus is dated.
See above, n. 4.
See above, n. 5.
Jewishness is indicated by his son’s designation – ̓Ιουδαίος (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.4.
The papyrus is dated.
See Introduction 2.3.1.
Jewishness indicated by son’s name, see under Shabtai (B/M), n. 269.
In Greek – ἱερατικὸς ἀρχοντικός.
Thought Jewish because of the titles, but both are not uniquely Jewish, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.3.
The vast majority of persons in this family have biblical names, which may suggest a Jewish family, but this is the Christian era, and they could be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.
The papyrus is dated.
See Introduction 6.1.6.2.1.
The inscription is dated.
Jewishness suggested by his presence in an otherwise all-Jewish ostracon form the “Jewish quarter” of Edfu, but see Introduction 6.1.5.2.
On the interchange of ε and ει see Introduction 2.3.3.2.
Jewishness indicated by reference to the archons of the politeuma, see Introduction 6.4.2.1. He is apparently a jailer and thus an official of the politeuma.
The papyrus is dated.

state.note: Epheboi inscription, Cyrene, Oliverio & Pugliese Carratelli

person.note: This person may be Jewish, because of his father’s name, see Introduction 6.6.8, but this is a pagan epheboi list, see Introduction 6.6.5.
The inscription is dated.
See Introduction 2.1.

Jewishness was suggested based on name of wife (but see under Dosithea [G/F], n. 1), absence of decoration and similarity to Jewish epitaphs of Leontopolis, see Introduction 6.5.1, but none of these are decisive.
On the loss of the first ι as a scribal error see Introduction 2.8.2. In the interchange of ι and ε see Introduction 2.3.3.2.
Designated in the inscription ̓Ιουδέῳ (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.3.

Jewishness suggested based on the assumption that if a person is ordered to appear before the Jewish politeuma of Heracleopolis (see Introduction 6.4.2.1), then he is Jewish, but that need not necessarily be so, see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
The papyrus is dated.
On the Aphrodisias inscription see Introduction 6.1.6.1.1.
See Introduction 2.3.1.
Jewishness may be suggested because of son’s name, but see under Dositheus (G/M), n. 1. His association with a certain Joseph (11) may enhance this impression, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
The ostracon is dated.
The inscription mentions Ex 34:7, but see Introduction 6.9.IJO 2 did not include this inscription, see p. 346, n. 16.
So according to Strubbe, “Curses,” 75.
The editors thought this is a description (fodder-dealer), but it is also a personal name.

In the Crimea.
Jewishness indicated by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
In Russia, on the north-eastern coast of the Black Sea.
Jewishness suggested based on son’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.3.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
In Latin – assidue tumultuantis.

It has been debated whether the Chrestus mentioned here is a Jewish agitator, or a misspelling of the word “Christus,” referring to Jesus, see with great doubts Stern, GLAJJ 2, p. 116, and with a little more credulity, Leon, Jews of Ancient Rome, 25-6. See also E. Gruen, Diaspora: Jews amidst Greeks and Romans (Cambridge MA 2002) 39.
For a discussion of the date see GLAJJ 2, p. 215-6.
The suffix is probably the Latin nominative, see Introduction 2.3.3.7.1.
In the Crimea.

There is nothing Jewish in this inscription except its typological similarity to other manumission inscriptions from the region, where the manumission was performed in the synagogue of the Jews, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.3. This inscription mentions the pagan gods Δία Γῆν ̔́Ηλιον (Zeus, Ge and Helios), see Introduction 6.10.2.
The inscription is dated to the reign of the king Tiberius Julius Sauromates II. These are his regnal years.
The suffix is probably the Latin genitive, see Introduction 2.3.3.7.1.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.
For the declension based on the form Χρυσᾶς, see Introduction 2.3.3.7.2.
Jewishness decided based on the formula – ̓Εν εἰρήνῃ κοίμη [σις αύτοῦ ] (in peace his sleep), see Introduction 6.10.3.5.
In Greek – ἐτῶν δύο.

The inscription includes the pagan formula Θ(έοι) Κ(αταχθονίοις) (to the gods of the underworld), see Introduction 6.10.2. It comes from the Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3, but the stone was probably reused.
See Introduction 6.1.6.2.1.
The inscription is dated.
On the Aphrodisias inscription see Introduction 6.1.6.1.1.
Jewishness suggested based on Jewish tombstones found on the site, but see Introduction 6.5.9, and Bohak, “Good Jews, Bad Jews.”

These are the dates of King Cotys mentioned in the inscription.

Greek, WGE, 55. This is the most popular Greek name among Jews (Cassuto-Salzmann, EI 3 [1954] 187). According to Jossippon, 56-7, the priests made a promise to Alexander the Great to call all their sons born that year (=330 BCE) Alexander. This story is hardly historical, but it may be an attempt to explain the popularity of the name among Jews. In S of S Rab 4:13 the name אלכסנדרי is interpreted as a popular transliteration of בנימין, but we have no concrete example to prove it, and see also Klein Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 326-7.
Name recorded in WGE, 56, but only for Jews. However, see LGPN I, 26; II, 20; IIIA, 25; IIIB, 22. In vol. 1, pp. 285-60, this name was recorded under the name Alexander, but see Introduction 2.3.

Greek, WGE, 330. On the theophoric element in this name, and the possibility of it being Jewish, see Introduction 1.2.3.1. Many scholars (e.g. Tcherikover,CPJ 1, xix, n. 7) identify this name as uniquely Jewish and proceed to identify persons by this name as Jews. However, this is a circular argument, since it is unlikely that such a Greek name was used exclusively by Jews, see Introduction 1.2.3.

Greek, WGE, 336. Eirene means peace. Scholars (e.g. Mussies, “Jewish Personal Names,” 245) identify this name as a translation of the Hebrew שלום and interpret it as an exclusively Jewish name. But it is Greek, and this assumption is thus unlikely, see Introduction 1.2.4.
WGE, 336 records the name Εἰρηνοποιώς but only for this person. Nevertheless, the name has a reasonable Greek meaning (maker of peace).

This is obviously a Greek name, since it employs the Greek word δοῦλος (slave), but this combination is unknown, and the first element in the name, the deity to which the person is enslaved, is probably the Jewish God – Iao, see Introduction 6.10.1.6.

Greek, WGE, 531. Jason was a famous mythical Greek hero who sailed after the Golden Fleece with the Argonauts, see Introduction 1.2.3. Some scholars (e.g. CJZC, p. 31) suggested that the name was particularly favored by Jews, and identified some persons as Jewish because of the name, but this is a circular argument and rejected in this corpus, see Introduction 1.2.4.

Greek, WGE, 568. Obviously derived from Εἰρήνη, which means peace. Scholars (e.g. Mussies, “Jewish Personal Names,” 245) identify this name as a translation of the Hebrew שלום and interpret it as an exclusively Jewish name. But it is Greek and this assumption is thus unlikely, see Introduction 1.2.4.
Greek, WGE, 571-2. This is a Greek theophoric name derived from the Egyptian goddess Isis, see Introduction 1.2.3.
Greek, WGE, 573. This is a Greek theophoric name derived from the Egyptian goddess Isis, see Introduction 1.2.3.
WGE did not know this form, but see LGPN I, 263.

The name Λεύκιος is understood by WGE, 789-90, as the Latin name Lucius. However, this is unlikely, because of the Greek names with the prefix Λευκ which predate Roman times, as some of the Jews with these names do, see ibid, pp. 787-92.
Greek, WGE, 910. The form Μητρότιμος is also recorded in WGE, 919.
Many Greek names begin with the prefix Μνας (see WGE, 933-5) but this one does not match any of them. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
Greek, WGE, 953. The name is reminiscent of the biblical Moses, but persons with this name are not necessarily Jewish, see Introduction 1.2.4.
WGEdid not know this name, but LGPN I, 323, and IIIA, 310, record the form Νάρδος and II, 325, records the (probably feminine) Νάρδιον, and see Introduction 2.3.
Greek, WGE, 986. This name includes the mythic Greek element “nectar,” see Introduction 1.2.3.
WGE, 1016, records the name Νουβαῖος, probably of the same root.
Greek, WGE, 1017. Further on this name in the Diaspora see Williams, JSJ 36 (2005).
WGE did not record this name, but see for example LGPN I, 340 and II, 343. See also previous name.
Greek, WGE, 1018. This name includes the mythic Greek element “nymph,” see Introduction 1.2.3.
Greek, WGE, 1021. This name includes the mythic Greek element “nymph,” see Introduction 1.2.3.
Greek, WGE, 1053-4. This name includes the mythic Greek element “Olympus,” see Introduction 1.2.3.
Greek, WGE, 1054-5. This name includes the mythic Greek element “Olympus,” see Introduction 1.2.3.
WGE did not know this form, but see LGPN IIIB, 327.
WGE did not know this form, but see LGPN II, 357.
WGE, 1129, thought this and related names were Roman, but this is unlikely, see e.g. LGPN IIIB, 333 or Preisigke, Namenbuch, 276.
Greek, WGE, 1130. WGE mentions only this person bearing this name, but it is obviously derived from Papus.
WGE did not record this name, but see e.g. LGPN I, 374 and II, 369.

Greek, WGE, 1241. This is a Greek theophoric name derived from the god Poseidon, see Introduction 1.2.3.

Greek, WGE, 1333. Further on this name in the Diaspora see Williams, JSJ 36 (2005) 35-6.
Greek, WGE, 1343-4. This is a Greek theophoric name derived from the (Hellenistic-Egyptian) god Sarapis, see Introduction 1.2.3.
Greek, WGE, 1351-3. This name includes the mythic Greek element “Satyr,” see Introduction 1.2.3.
Greek, WGE, 1371. This is a Greek theophoric name derived from the (Hellenistic-Egyptian) god Sarapis, see Introduction 1.2.3.

Many Greek names begin with the prefix Σινδ (see WGE, 1395) but this one does not match any of them. It may be a scribal error or a misreading of the inscription.
WGE did not know this name, but see LGPN IIIA, 408. The name is also recorded often on Egyptian papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 398.
Greek, WGE, 1528. On the theophoric element in this name, and the possibility of it being Jewish, see Introduction 1.2.3.1.
Greek, WGE, 1572. This is probably a Greek theophoric name, mentioning the Greek goddess of fortune Tyche, see Introduction 1.2.3.
Greek, WGE, 1572. This is probably a Greek theophoric name, mentioning the Greek goddess of fortune Tyche, see Introduction 1.2.3.
WGE did not know this form, but see LGPN I, 450.
Although I have not found this name recorded elsewhere, it has such a plain Greek meaning (bearer of bounty) that is must be considered Greek.
WGE did not know this form as a Greek name, but see LGPN I, 459.
WGE did not know this form, but see LGPN II, 448, IIIA, 449.
This name is obviously a combination of the biblical Shabtai (שבתי) and the Greek Φίλος (=friend/lover). It is not recorded elsewhere.
WGE did not know this name, but see LGPN IIIB, 439.
